title: Grade 11: United States History II: World War I to Present
subject: Social Studies (2024-)

98E7DFF678FA4B95ACA955D35B00AC70.description: Describe the significance of national elections from 1992 to the present, including the 2000 presidential recount in Florida and 2008 election of Barack Obama.

0F922AD3ADDD48898BD7A959973F1C4B.description: Assess how political events beginning with the Clinton presidency and into the early 2000s contributed to growing political polarization.

E3A9A6D7400841CB969E68FB185AADB6.description: Evaluate how federal policies and legislation have shaped American society since 1988.

273100F4AAEF42B1993D6A544511C418.description: Assess the economic and political effects of immigration on the United States and explain how immigration policies have evolved in the post-Cold War era.

E1393F7CFEE74897B81BF5410248EF46.description: Trace the evolution of the environmental movement and political debate over climate change from the 1980s to the present, including how environmental and natural disasters have shaped the discussion.

A30A86F3CA554FC7B9213E4BD1AF228D.description: Evaluate how political developments and technology shaped economic trends and fluctuations from the 1990s into the early twenty-first century.

0B358ED71E994BC9977AE5C3B29C536E.description: Compare and contrast Operation Desert Storm and Operation Iraqi Freedom, including why they took place, the domestic political consequences of United States’ involvement in these conflicts, and the international implications for these wars.

2B06D274F40A4AFDBC0B82413B82E861.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of the United States’ response to the September 11 attacks, including the war in Afghanistan, creation of the Department of Homeland Security, and passage of the USA PATRIOT Act.

0002457E37644025B337D1A4F4D23A67.description: Investigate the role and influence of the United States in peacekeeping efforts around the world from the 1990s into the early twenty-first century.

320027276C63461F88B943F3C92DD6DD.description: Analyze the shifts in United States foreign policy and challenges to it after the Cold War and into the twenty-first century.

76F0C113BE734F778BCD807CBBF142DB.description: Trace the series of events during Reagan’s presidency leading to the emergence of the United States as the sole superpower, the fall of the Berlin Wall, and the collapse of the Soviet Union.

76990F3CB2D149E7A6F96318806ECA7D.description: Analyze how Reaganomics and deregulation affected the American economy and society.

32D6E26764BE4068A930CEA90B6F7FCE.description: Describe the growth and composition of movement conservatism beginning in the 1960s, and explain how this culminated in the formation of the Reagan Coalition and led to his election in 1980.

8F91D1E2B8A6442FBFF3778A1D415956.description: Analyze the conservative revolution in American politics and how this shaped Ronald Reagan’s domestic and foreign policies.

D5D0BBA29A334D51BF7115295C9D77D8.description: Evaluate how the United States’ increasing involvement in the Middle East during the 1970s affected both the region and the United States itself.

CA0C01A4DF9649CCB50CEE8668EC9379.description: Analyze how America’s foreign policy decisions in the Vietnam War shaped Cold War actions in the 1970s, including détente and increased concern for human rights.

D593CD0A4FDD4AF6BDD5A814FD96F819.description: Describe significant foreign policy events during the presidencies of Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, and Jimmy Carter that decreased hostility in the Cold War.

7CA5D6EF2C6544F8BB407D74D62E90BE.description: Identify the reasons for the economic fluctuations of the 1970s and evaluate the effectiveness of government action on the problem of stagflation.

8214CCEE1E784B9D80B43D1A0DF14D44.description: Outline the events that led to the Watergate scandal and brought about the resignation of President Richard Nixon and the presidency of Gerald Ford.

DE55FC987ADF44BBA55E961F26D2F0BA.description: Trace the events that fostered the emergence of the modern environmental movement and prompted government regulations as well as civic action.

3B83BD7A4CE840DC92CF15685F9D9975.description: Describe how significant domestic events during the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter shaped United States economics, politics, and society.

28D184A3194C4DAE9A8B4D1FB53785BB.description: Compare and contrast major Supreme Court decisions from the 1960s through the 1980s and explain how they reflect an ongoing national debate regarding the expansion and limits of civil liberties, civil rights, and constitutional protections.

1FFD60FF16974BAD8143B3A02083FE1B.description: Evaluate the social and political significance of the women’s rights movement from the 1960s to the 1980s on the lives of women in the United States.

1B972E9712B5419E92600EA63380A863.description: Explain how the Civil Rights Movement inspired other movements for civil and human rights, and describe the contributions of groups and individuals to these movements.

C399D51BA1254E028AABB9604B74D186.description: Explain shifts in the scope of the Civil Rights Movement from the mid-1960s into the 1970s, including geographic regions, issues of focus, and participation.

EEAF52378B124C3FBD51271AF87114EB.description: Evaluate the relationship between domestic social movements, including the New Left and counterculture movements, and America’s war in Vietnam and explain how the movements and the war each influenced public perception of the other.

EB903F3AD747488889929EA44993461A.description: Describe how significant events in the Vietnam War resulted in a decline of public support for American involvement in the conflict.

619A225002F54A5CAD2F336DF8DBD4DE.description: Investigate and explain the effects of the domino theory and the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution on United States involvement in the Vietnam conflict.

FBF83CC6186C4971BBE12ABAC35FD2BE.description: Assess the effectiveness of John F. Kennedy’s foreign policy toward Cuba, including the Bay of Pigs invasion and the Cuban Missile Crisis.

EFFA82E6C349403786D5A2C1D99EFD24.description: Explain the evolution of America’s Cold War policy to defend democracy and contain communism around the world and how this led to an escalation in armed conflict during the 1960s.

5B528E7A93F241E7B906333FC4324845.description: Investigate the major elements of Lyndon Johnson’s Great Society program and explain how it represents an attempt to expand the American social safety net, including the War on Poverty, Medicare, Medicaid, and Head Start.

548C00A51CA0450EBFC8DA615C10CA1E.description: Compare and contrast major domestic initiatives of John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and explain how Kennedy’s assassination led to both change and continuity in these initiatives.

F482FC516ABF4C909E1EB2E208176391.description: Describe the demographic and political changes that occurred as some populations shifted from cities to suburbs.

DB0B23B6B87B4F50ADD5D698D5BEF263.description: Evaluate the effects of the arms and space races on the growth of the military-industrial complex.

BB58A53BC2024E5DB6F87BD28BEF5643.description: Analyze how cultural changes, economic growth, and government action during the Truman and Eisenhower administrations shaped the daily lives of Americans.

EA57AC9BD3B04B709D5CBD390BB4D0FB.description: Describe how key Alabamians provided leadership, generated change, or demonstrated resistance to the Civil Rights Movement.

80780D0D41D84C05BEA5D7A5ADAA275B.description: Summarize the political, economic, and physical means by which opponents of the Civil Rights Movement sought to limit its achievements.

EBBF1754D7C64537BF020FA15F26A59E.description: Compare and contrast the actions and philosophies of key civil rights leaders and organizations, including Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Malcolm X.

11DE65AC368A4C9CB0E9BA6EE1C363D0.description: Analyze the extent to which the actions and campaigns of civil rights activists and organizations from 1954 to 1965 prompted federal measures to advance civil and human rights.

CB2694E38DA548A3A96B9A9AF5D16C12.description: Identify and explain key events from 1945 to 1955 that brought about the emergence of a large-scale movement for civil rights.

20F6FA0297104E7BA26D704393076A79.description: Evaluate the influence of events, organizations, and individual actions on the expansion of the Civil Rights Movement nationally.

3A0B6A6DAE5045A69110D7D8E8BCC87D.description: Analyze the domestic responses to the Cold War, including the impact of McCarthyism.

C196FEC5110642E1BD9901596546799F.description: Identify and explain the origins of the United States’ involvement in the Korean War and the consequences of Harry Truman’s limited war plan for Korea.

AE0017292DDF4BBFA00A2A409E458695.description: Compare the application of the United States’ policy of containment to various areas of the world outside the Soviet Union in the late 1940s and 1950s.

5166F9B06F5C4BF295827E6A46747E4B.description: Develop an argument regarding the effectiveness of the United States policy of containment that resulted from its growing ideological and political tensions with the Soviet Union.

659E29E20EC041769D25271FD83E28B9.description: Outline the foreign policy changes that led the United States into the Cold War and contributed to its emergence as a superpower.

6D06D4F4F1ED4D8F83042994D4649BE5.description: Describe how World War II led to advances in mass media, medicine, science, and technology.

E6001B156A5C427BBF58BC4A7F7F9C5B.description: Describe the experiences of Japanese Americans in World War II, including their internment on the home front and military contributions in Europe to Allied victory.

64172A375377471597A85D28CB8539F0.description: Explain how minority groups organized to gain access to wartime jobs and how they confronted discrimination, including the Bracero Program and Double V Campaign.

03F8356C0A3F45E0B885E2AE17AB4676.description: Describe Alabama's participation in World War II, including the role of the Tuskegee Airmen, housing prisoner of war (POW) camps, growth of the Port of Mobile, production of steel in Birmingham, and the establishment of military bases.

22C2CF898039457C9A65D4E5EBF49F8E.description: Analyze the domestic, economic, and civil rights impact of World War II on United States society.

70470F1BA05F4481A34D7743A2FE359A.description: Explain how key consequences of World War II shaped United States foreign policy after the war.

6D7CCAA77F3E4230B4C1A839302ECDCC.description: Describe the role of the United States military in helping end the Holocaust, including the liberation of concentration camps and participation in the Nuremberg Trials.

A6D39E70604A4B6E9629FBFD03159DD9.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of United States strategies in the war, including the decision to utilize atomic weapons on Japan.

B0CDF7305FE544F78AFD5C5CF6A9AF00.description: Compare and contrast the roles and leadership of United States leaders in securing victory for the Allied powers during World War II.

35F4887767564F2F9748E632EE2BC629.description: Develop an argument supporting the thesis that major battles of World War II in which the United States was involved were turning points of the war and outline the impact of these battles on territorial occupation by the Allied and Axis powers.

AB895E4E6F9F49D1ACA045DCC475DFFA.description: Analyze how United States military involvement shaped major events of World War II.

68741798FA5D48CEBB1FBB5707FE993A.description: Critique the evolving United States policy and public attitudes toward Nazi Germany and the growing refugee crisis as the Holocaust began.

0A2A16B1248C4A33872E47F079608885.description: Summarize the United States’ foreign policies of isolationism and internationalism as World War II began and explain how the bombing of Pearl Harbor affected this approach.

8EF9219386694134A674BE5B865919CE.description: Trace the progression of events and policies leading to World War II and the United States’ entry into the war.

9FC219CDDD804F3589FA7EE30AA223E2.description: Analyze the impact of the Great Depression and the resulting social programs on the American family and minority groups.

82DCD89455184B7398D69C6E5EA0DEE2.description: Describe the effects of New Deal programs on Alabama, outlining the problems they sought to address.

259B04635DFF4A8397F719149379D579.description: Identify economic and social effects of the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl on American society and describe how individuals addressed the challenges and sought to help others in need.

68B99316D28E4D4E9EFEA4CF7A7949F4.description: Critique the effectiveness of the New Deal in managing problems of the Great Depression through relief, recovery, and reform programs; expansion of the executive branch; and the application of Keynesian economic theory.

B9393E6863644AA5BA3325897B88F499.description: Differentiate between the ways Herbert Hoover and Franklin Roosevelt dealt with the Great Depression.

5EDD90A32BCE4CFCA4B5D1D31A1C1011.description: Analyze the causes of the Great Depression, including the effects of overproduction, stock market speculation, buying on credit, international trade policy, and restrictive monetary policies.

0D9C3786690949C6AC616C19FEFCFA14.description: Trace the causes and course of Red Summer and subsequent violence into the 1920s, including the Tulsa Race Massacre.

0379489D9E594AAEA845FCCE0DF6A4CF.description: Summarize the debate over prohibition and describe how prohibition contributed to social and cultural changes of the 1920s.

0217211167B24E9BAA9CB9237740F13F.description: Explain why the 1920s comprised a period of significant social conflict as manifested by the Scopes trial, growth of the Ku Klux Klan, rise of nativist thinking, the Red Scare, and antisemitism.

30455F06D87643418753ABC021433107.description: Explain how art, literature, and music, including that produced by Alabamians, influenced both the Harlem Renaissance and the broader culture of the 1920s.

1CFF2E008FDE47E0BDBB9ACA9974C10B.description: Describe how the automobile, cinema, print media, and radio contributed to the rise in mass culture, economic growth, and expansion of the middle class during the 1920s.

45200D5E6EED4316A962E9DBD0FBF7A9.description: Evaluate how key figures, events, and trends shaped United States society and culture from the conclusion of World War I through the 1920s.

816484C675F64393A9E24F18D36CCF95.description: Roaring Twenties and the Great Depression

57E05D47FFFF46E985B94E8D47BADB92.description: Compare the reasons given by opposing sides in the debate over whether the United States should ratify the Treaty of Versailles (1919).

5C88DB2A19FE49D2A05CA2FA716D9648.description: Analyze how government actions in the United States during World War I produced both economic growth and social division.

D96C8E825F1540D5A824B67BA6333A63.description: Describe the changing roles and rights of women in the United States that resulted from their contributions to World War I and ratification of the Nineteenth Amendment.

BCBCFFCD6E784FE0A82EDD5DDF9EF202.description: Describe the roles of Black Americans as members of the military and on the home front during World War I, including the Harlem Hellfighters and the Great Migration.

C1563D5C08A24659A5089B07D28A8A25.description: Trace United States military involvement in World War I and the contributions of the American Expeditionary Force to the victory of the Allied Powers.

68A27A2C09D94FFE8C8243988140525C.description: Summarize the events and factors that led to the United States entry into World War I.

63585F49011C476BA82B21FA808FD75F.description: Compare and contrast the arguments of those in the United States who advocated for preparedness and those who sought neutrality from 1914 to 1917.

409E75EA7016449FA44D52100D8B75ED.description: Trace United States’ interventions around the world under Theodore Roosevelt’s Big Stick Diplomacy, William Howard Taft’s Dollar Diplomacy, and Woodrow Wilson’s Moral Diplomacy.

276AAA5A1CBD4BF68E4840FCA56F35DA.description: Describe the consequences of the Spanish-American War, including the United States’ rise to global prominence, debate over territorial expansion, and military intervention in Cuba and the Philippines.

3B38AB442D394B62BCEF7A52777DFFBB.description: Explain how yellow journalism, jingoistic sentiments, and economic interests led to American entry into war with Spain.

130721DDCC6347D8AE7A924D6BBE6846.description: Summarize conflicting viewpoints over the United States’ role in the world from the Spanish-American War to its entry into World War I.
